passages.text: Economics - Asia ex-Japan

Activity data broadly slowed in July and disappointed markets. Weak growth momentum is likely to be sustained in August, despite the onshore stock market rally. We expect the PMIs to remain low, export and IP growth to moderate, and retail sales growth to remain subdued. Daily average stock trading volume soared to a record high of RMB2.3trn in August, but its positive spillovers to the real economy might be quite limited. Chinese households' assets are still concentrated in property, while the salaries of financial practitioners remain largely capped. The rising growth headwinds call for more policy support, but deploying pro- growth measures might risk causing a stock market bubble. In our view, Beijing's best strategy is to draw lessons from the past, resist the temptation to fuel the stock markets through high- profile monetary measures in the near term, remain vigilant by avoiding contractionary policies, clean up the property mess, and address some deep- rooted problems such as the unequal social security system.

In view of slowing exports, the ongoing anti- involution campaign, the payback effect from the consumer trade- in program, and the subdued EPMI print, we expect the official manufacturing PMI to remain muted at 49.3 in August, unchanged from July. The RatingDog manufacturing PMI (formerly Caixin manufacturing PMI), which surveys more SMEs and exporters, is likely to remain subdued at 49.8 in August from 49.5 in July. We expect the official non- manufacturing PMI to edge down to 50.0 in August from 50.1 in July, weighed on by the ongoing austerity rules and falling seasonal summer holiday demand, though the stock market boom could provide some support.

On major activity data, we expect export growth to moderate to \(5.5\%\) y- o- y in August from \(7.2\%\) in July, owing to a high base. We forecast IP, retail sales and FAI growth of \(5.3\%\) \(3.8\%\) and \(0.2\%\) y- o- y, respectively, in August, compared with \(5.8\%\) \(3.7\%\) and \(- 5.2\%\) in July.

We expect negative CPI inflation, less negative PPI inflation and lower credit growth Due to a significant drag from food prices, we expect CPI inflation to turn negative in August, falling to \(- 0.2\%\) y- o- y from \(0.0\%\) in July, while excluding food and energy, core CPI inflation is likely to rise further on a low base.

We expect PPI deflation to ease to \(- 2.8\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 3.6\%\) in July, as major commodity prices have risen amid the anti- involution campaign. On a sequential basis, we forecast PPI inflation to turn positive at \(0.1\%\) m- o- m in August, recovering from July's - \(0.2\%\) and above the \(- 0.7\%\) m- o- m recorded in August 2024.

We expect credit growth - measured as year- on- year growth in outstanding aggregate financing(AF) - to slow to \(8.8\%\) y- o- y in August from \(9.0\%\) in July, due mainly to a notably high base in government bond issuance. Growth in outstanding RMB loans is likely to remain unchanged at \(6.9\%\) y- o- y in August.
Official manufacturing PMI in August: 49.3 (July: 49.3)
Official non- manufacturing PMI in August: 50.0 (July: 50.1)
RatingDog manufacturing PMI in August: 49.8 (July: 49.5)

In view of the slowing momentum of export, the ongoing anti- involution campaign, the payback effect from the consumer trade- in program, and subdued EPMI print, we expect the official manufacturing PMI to remain muted at 49.3 in August, unchanged from July. China's EPMI, a non- seasonally adjusted leading indicator of the official PMI, increased by 1.0pp to 46.8 in August from 47.9 in July, smaller than the historical July- to- August average increase of 1.4pp.

We expect the official non- manufacturing PMI to drop to 50.0 in August from 50.1 in July, weighed on by the ongoing austerity rules and falling seasonal summer holiday demand, though the stock market boom could provide some support. Meanwhile, the PMI for the construction sector is likely to drop based on high- frequency data.

We expect the RatingDog manufacturing PMI (formerly Caixin manufacturing PMI), which surveys more SMEs and exporters in the eastern coastal region of China, to remain subdued at 49.8 in August from 49.5 in July. Growth in Korea's exports to China improved to \(2.7\%\) y- o- y in 1- 20 August from \(- 3.0\%\) in July, while its imports from China edged down to \(3.8\%\) y- o- y in 1- 20 August from \(4.0\%\) in July.

We expect industrial production (IP) growth to soften to \(5.3\%\) y- o- y in August from \(5.7\%\) in July, mainly weighed on by weaker exports. High- frequency activity indicators point to mixed industrial activity, as detailed below:

The weekly operating rate of cement factories improved to 4.1pp below its year- ago level in month- to- date August from 8.2pp below its July average. The weekly cement shipment- to- output ratio increased to 4.3pp above its year- ago level in month- to- date August from 3.1pp above its July average. Growth in weekly steel rebar output at major steel mills surged to \(29.8\%\) y- o- y in month- to- date August from \(- 3.3\%\) in July, driven by a low base from last year. The operating rate of asphalt factories edged down to 4.7pp above its year- ago level in month- to- date August from 5.9pp above its year- ago level in July. Growth in the daily average volume of coal burned at power plants in eight provinces in South China fell to \(0.9\%\) y- o- y in month- to- date August from \(3.4\%\) in July.

We expect CPI inflation to turn negative at \(- 0.2\%\) y- o- y in August, following July's \(0.0\%\) reading. The decline is primarily attributable to weaker- than- seasonal food price patterns. In sequential terms, we project CPI to increase by \(0.3\%\) m- o- m in August, up from \(- 0.2\%\) in July but still below the \(0.4\%\) m- o- m gain recorded in August 2024.

We project food prices to decline by \(- 4.6\%\) y- o- y in August, a steeper drop from July's - \(1.6\%\) . The decline partly reflects the lunar calendar mismatch, as this year has an intercalary sixth month, which affects the timing of seasonal supply and demand. This forecast is also supported by the MARA agricultural product wholesale price index, which fell sharply to \(- 10.4\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 3.1\%\) in July, mainly dragged down by vegetable prices. In the meat category, wholesale prices of pork remained largely steady at RMB20.2/kg in August versus RMB20.6/kg in July. On a year- over- year basis though pork prices dropped to \(- 24.9\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 16.9\%\) in July.

For the non- food components, we expect the y- o- y increase in core prices to rise to \(1.2\%\) in August from \(0.8\%\) in July, driven by a lower base from last year, as well as elevated gold prices. The energy component in the non- food category could also offer some support. The NDRC implemented a RMB180 per tonne decrease in petrol prices in August. While this contrasts with July's RMB105 hike, it represents an uplift from the RMB305 reduction in August 2024, which should positively impact the energy component of the CPI basket in y- o- y terms.

We expect PPI deflation to ease to \(- 2.8\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 3.6\%\) in July, as major commodity prices have risen amid the anti- involution campaign. On a sequential basis, we forecast PPI inflation to turn positive at \(0.1\%\) m- o- m in August, recovering from July's - \(0.2\%\) and above the \(- 0.7\%\) m- o- m recorded in August 2024. This improvement reflects widespread increases across key raw material prices. The panhua price index for industrial products increased to \(- 3.2\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 9.2\%\) in July. The NBS's 50 raw material price survey - which we view as a more reliable PPI leading indicator - shows prices rose to \(- 7.2\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 10.0\%\) in July.

We expect retail sales growth to remain tepid at \(3.8\%\) y- o- y in August from \(3.7\%\) in July, weighed on by the payback effect from the trade- in program and the ongoing austerity rule. However, a lower base from last year, the fiscal subsidy for childbirth and school fee exemptions, and the deployment of a third batch of trade- in subsidy, could provide some support. By components, we expect retail sales growth in auto, catering and merchandise excluding autos of \(- 2.0\%\) y- o- y, \(1.0\%\) and \(4.9\%\) , respectively, in August (July: \(- 1.5\%\) y- o- y, \(1.1\%\) , and \(4.7\%\) ).

On auto sales, according to early estimates from the CPCA, volume growth in passenger car retail sales is likely to drop to \(1.7\%\) y- o- y in August from \(7.3\%\) in July. Considering the continued price competition among key automakers, we expect auto sales in value terms, as reported by the NBS, to turn more negative in August.

The catering sector might remain muted by the new austerity rules, which restrict dining out by government officials and SOE managers (Asia Special Report - The trade- in program and the new austerity rule, 24 June 2025).

For merchandise sales excluding autos, we expect continued weakness mainly due to the trade- in program's payback effects. Two sets of subsidies are being deployed in August. According to the NDRC, the third batch of the trade- in program subsidy (RMB81bn) was deployed in August, with scope expanded to include the subsidized group including education- related electronic products. According to the State Council, the childbirth subsidy for this year will be distributed from late August. However, in our view, the payback effect could more than offset by the renewed deployment of the trade- in subsidy, and household with children may choose to smooth out the childbirth subsidy overtime.

We expect export growth to moderate to \(5.5\%\) y- o- y in August from \(7.2\%\) in July, due to a high base and a sharp slowdown in export- delivered value in July. Higher frequency data point to a mixed bag, with faster container throughput but weaker freight rates and cross- border cargo flights.

Export growth improved in July, defying an expected slowdown by markets and ourselves. We correctly forecast a sharper contraction in exports to the US, as suggested by high frequency data on container bookings and freight rates, while shipments to non- US markets accelerated unexpectedly. In hindsight, weekly container throughput data at major ports proved to be a more effective leading indicator, as its growth increased to \(3.9\%\) y- o- y in July from \(3.6\%\) in June, aligned with improved headline exports. In August, container throughput has improved further, with its y- o- y growth rising markedly to \(7.9\%\) in 1- 24 August. Meanwhile, growth in the number of total cross- border cargo flights moderated to \(10.6\%\) y- o- y in 1- 24 August from \(12.0\%\) in July, due to a higher base.

Moreover, Korea's exports have been resilient in August. Growth in Korea's overall exports picked up to \(7.6\%\) y- o- y in 1- 20 August from \(5.9\%\) in July, excluding working- day adjustments. On Korea's trade with China, export growth rose to \(2.7\%\) y- o- y in 1- 20 August from \(- 3.0\%\) in July, while import growth softened to \(3.8\%\) from \(4.0\%\) .

On US- bound exports, growth in container bookings dipped further to \(- 26.3\) y- o- y in the week of 4 August from \(- 20.9\%\) in July and \(- 14.3\%\) in June, according to Vizion, a US supply chain intelligence firm. According to GeekYum, a widely used global shipping rates search- engine based in Shanghai, forward freight rates from China to US West Coast fell
to a daily average of \~USD3,000/FEU in August- September from \~USD3,300/FEU in July. Falling container bookings and freight rates indicate reduced demand for shipments to the US.

On overall freight rates, the China Containerized Freight Index (CCFI), which measures the average shipping price of containers from China's 10 major ports to other parts of the world, dropped by \(6.9\%\) over the past month (from end- July to end- August). Geographically, the CCFI fell by \(1.7\%\) to Europe and by \(9.3\%\) to the US East Coast over the same period.

We expect import growth to increase slightly to \(4.4\%\) y- o- y in August from \(4.1\%\) in July, thanks to a low base. The year- over- year change in the China Import Dry Bulk Freight Index (CDFI), which reflects freight rates of dry bulk cargo (including iron ore, coal, grain and nickel ore) imported to China, increased markedly to \(- 6.8\%\) y- o- y in month- to- date August from \(- 15.2\%\) in July. Growth in Brent oil prices increased to \(- 15.4\%\) in August- to- date from \(- 18.1\%\) in July.
Combining our forecasts of exports and imports, the trade surplus is likely to increase marginally to USD99bn in August from USD98bn in July.

We expect FAI growth to rebound to \(0.2\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 5.2\%\) in July, which implies year- to- date growth will decline further to \(1.4\%\) y- o- y from \(1.6\%\) . This rebound in FAI growth is largely a reversal of some of the falls caused by adverse weather conditions in July, which the NBS said was the key reason for the undershoot of FAI growth last month. The rebound is likely primarily supported by infrastructure, while the manufacturing sector remains an unknown given the ongoing "anti- involution" campaign. Moreover, the property sector is likely to remain a severe drag, as we forecast another hefty contraction (see section below).

We expect property investment growth to drop further to \(- 17.8\%\) in August from \(- 17.1\%\) in July. Year- to- date growth in property investment is also likely to decline to \(- 12.7\%\) y- o- y in August, from \(- 12.0\%\) in July.

Based on a sample of 20 major cities covered by Wind, growth in new home sales volumes increased again but remained in negative territory of \(- 10.5\%\) y- o- y in month- to- date August, from \(- 18.6\%\) in July. Compared with 2019 levels, growth in new home sales improved to \(- 56.0\%\) in month- to- date August from \(- 60.9\%\) in July. Contract sales volumes of the top 100 developers improved slightly to \(- 18.6\%\) y- o- y in July from \(- 25.5\%\) in April, according to the CRIC.

We believe the property sector will continue to contract, with investment growth still at a negative, high single- digit pace decline through August. The policy pivot in late September 2024 might be unable to rescue the sector, especially as the economy faces a double whammy from the property and export sectors. The ongoing price decline in 2025 lends further support to our long- held view that the property meltdown in China has yet to end, and more measures are needed (see our thematic report, The second wave of shocks, 5 September 2024).
New RMB loans in August: RMB781bn (July: - RMB50bn)
Outstanding AF growth in August: \(8.8\%\) y- o- y (July: \(9.0\%\) )
Outstanding RMB loan growth in August: \(6.9\%\) y- o- y (July: \(6.9\%\) )

We expect credit growth - measured as year- on- year growth in outstanding aggregate financing (AF) to drop to \(8.8\%\) y- o- y in August from \(9.0\%\) in July, due mainly to a high base from government bond issuance. Growth in outstanding RMB loans is likely to stay at a historical low of \(6.9\%\) y- o- y in August, unchanged from July.
In level terms, we forecast new AF and RMB loans of RMB2,418bn and RMB781bn, respectively, in August, versus year- ago levels of RMB3,032bn and RMB900bn.

On bond issuance, according to Wind's estimates using deal- level bond data, net government bond financing - for both central and local governments - has been RMB1,329bn in August as of 28 August, below its year- ago level of RMB1,841bn.

Looking at a breakdown, net financing of central government bonds (CGBs) decreased to RMB849bn from RMB1,022bn a year earlier, while that of local government bonds (LGBs) also dropped to RMB480bn from RMB819bn. On LGBs, local government special refinancing bonds (LGSRBs) contributed RMB54bn. LGSRBs are used exclusively for replacing local government hidden debt.
For other major bonds, net corporate bond financing was RMB73bn in August as of 28 August, below its year- ago level of RMB110bn.
Net bond financing for LGFVs was - RMB18bn, above its year- ago level of - RMB85bn. For property developers, their net bond financing was RMB11.9bn, above its year- ago level of RMB0.3bn.

Short- term liquidity conditions have still been stable in August. The average of DR007 fell to 1.479% in August from 1.516% in July but is still well above the PBoC's 7- day OMO reserve repo rate of 1.40%, while the monthly average of 10yr CGB yields edged up slightly to 1.746% from 1.678%.
Fig. 1: Forecast for August economic indicators
